Blog/ The Build

Date: 3rd Oct 16

The Build

I started by looking around at different examples of sites I liked and how I would like my site to feel. With me not having much prior knowledge to building sites I decided I wanted to keep it simple and straightforward yet building it in Mobile First allowed me to explore something that I had never done before.

Ideas

I wanted all the information to be easily accessible so therefore I decided to have quick links on my homepage which would allow users to quickly jump to my work, my blog or my contact page. All the icons used on this site are from Flat Icon.

When thinking about starting this portfolio site I thought about how most people may view it. The main people viewing my site will be potential employers, with this in mind I decided to create my site Mobile First.

Mobile First

The main reason I went for Mobile First is because of the amount of people that now purely use just their phone for browsing the internet. The graph below shows that the number of global users for mobile has risen dramatically and has now overtaken the number of desktop users.

An article from A List Apart explains that because of the rise in the number of people viewing from mobile is it important to make sure you site is fully responsive for smaller screens and generates a good experience;

“If your content isn’t available on mobile—or provides a bad reading experience—you’re missing out on one of the most compelling ways to get people to read it”

Wireframes

I started my design by just sketching on paper some rough ideas for the layout of the site. I wanted my homepage to contain quick links for the site, especially in mobile as it saves people having to click the hamburger icon for those main pages. I wanted some key words to stand out on my homepage and decided to make them the blue ( #339999) and also chose Waterlily Font because I thought it gave it a more personal approach.

Mobile Navigation

This is one of the first hurdles that I can across, I decided that would put the nav inside the hamburger icon using JavaScript and that would be the best way to show my navigation for mobile devices. If my site had been bigger I would have also had a navigation at the bottom that wasn’t hidden on mobile to save people having to scroll back to the top of the site. When searching about responsive navigations I came across the W3C page and used aspects of their JavaScript in order to allow me to have a hamburger icon that acted upon a click.

Accessibility

I wanted my site to be accessible. I included skip links so that if the user was visiting the site and using a screen reader they could skip to content, I didn’t need to skip to nav as my navigation was placed at the top of the page.

On all my images I have included Alt Text,Web Access explains that, "good Alt text should contain the message you wish to convey through that image, and if the image includes text, that text should also be included in the alt."

To check the colour contrast I have done the contrast checker and the site passed AA for larger text above 18point or 14point bold and I am only using it for main headings.

Finally

I have learnt a lot during the process of building this site, by making mistakes and thinking about why bits didn’t work was the best way for me to learn where I had gone wrong. I will keep adding and improving this site and welcome any feedback or comments that you may have.
